sen.j: 海住山寺（かいじゅうせんじ）は、京都府木津川市加茂町にある真言宗智山派の仏教寺院。
sen.e: Kaijusen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kaijusen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kaijusen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan School of the Shingon Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: かつて恭仁京があった瓶原（みかのはら）を見下ろす三上山（海住山）中腹に位置する。
sen.e: It is situated on the side of Mt. Mikami-yama (Kaijuzan), overlooking Kimanohara which used to be the site of Kuni-kyo City.
It is situated on the side of Mt. Mikami-yama (Kaijuzan), overlooking Kimanohara which used to be the site of Kuni-kyo City.
It is situated on the side of Mt. Mikami (Mt. Kaiju), overlooking Mikanohara which used to be the site of Kuni-kyo City.

sen.j: 山号は補陀洛山（ふだらくさん）、本尊は十一面観音。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Fudarakusan and the principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Fudarakusan and the principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Fudarakusan and the principal image is the Eleven-faced Kannon.

sen.j: 聖武天皇が盧舎那仏像（東大寺大仏）造立工事の無事を祈るために建てたものと伝わる。
sen.e: The temple is said to have been constructed by Emperor Shomu to pray for the safe construction of the Rushanabutsu-zo statue (Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple).
The temple is said to have been constructed by Emperor Shomu to pray for the safe construction of the Rushanabutsu-zo statue (Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple).
The temple is said to have been constructed by the Emperor Shomu to pray for the safe construction of the Rushanabutsu-zo statue (Great Buddha at Todai-ji Temple).

sen.j: 仏塔古寺十八尊第三番。
sen.e: It is the third temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas Pilgrimage.
sen.cmt: 仏塔古寺十八尊第三番→the third temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas (Holy Places of Butto-koji)[http://nippon-kichi.jp/article_list.do?kwd=3012&ml_lang=en]
sen.e: It is the third temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas Pilgrimage.
It is the third temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas Pilgrimage.

sen.j: 当寺の創建事情については必ずしも明らかではないが、寺伝では天平7年（735年）、 聖武天皇の勅願により良弁（ろうべん、奈良東大寺の初代別当）を開山として藤尾山観音寺という寺号で開創したという。
sen.e: The details surrounding the founding of Kaijusen-ji Temple are not entirely clear but, according to temple legend, it was founded in the year 735 under the name 'Fujioyama Kannon-ji Temple' by Roben (the first priest of Todai-ji Temple in Nara) on the order of Emperor Shomu.

The details surrounding the founding of Kaijusen-ji Temple are not entirely clear but, according to temple legend, it was founded in the year 735 under the name 'Fujioyama Kannon-ji Temple' by Roben (the first priest of Todai-ji Temple in Nara) on the order of Emperor Shomu.

The details surrounding the founding of Kaijusen-ji Temple are not entirely clear but, according to temple legend, it was founded in the year 735 under the name 'Fujioyama Kannon-ji Temple' by Roben (the first priest of Todai-ji Temple in Nara) on the order of the Emperor Shomu.

sen.j: その後、保延3年（1137年）に全山焼失し、承元2年（1208年）、笠置寺の貞慶（じょうけい）によって中興され、現在の山号と寺号に改められた。
sen.e: The entire temple was destroyed by fire in 1137 but was restored by Jokei of Kasagi-dera Temple in 1208 and its name was changed to the current 'Kaijusen-ji Temple'.
The entire temple was destroyed by fire in 1137 but was restored by Jokei of Kasagi-dera Temple in 1208 and its name was changed to the current 'Kaijusen-ji Temple'.

The entire temple was destroyed by fire in 1137 but was restored by Jokei of Kasagi-dera Temple in 1208 and its sango and jigo (literally, "temple name"), which is the title given to a Buddhist temple was changed to the current ones'.

sen.j: 貞慶は解脱上人とも称する平安時代末期-鎌倉時代初期の法相宗の僧で、南都仏教と戒律の復興に努めた。
sen.e: Jokei, also known as Priest Gedatsu, was a Hosso Sect monk who lived from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period and put great efforts into reviving Nanto Buddhism and religious discipline.

Jokei, also known as Priest Gedatsu, was a Hosso Sect monk who lived from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period and put great efforts into reviving Nanto Buddhism and religious discipline.

Jokei, also known as Priest Gedatsu, was a Hosso Sect monk who lived from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period and put great efforts into reviving Nanto Buddhism and religious discipline.

sen.j: 海住山寺も法相宗に属し、近世まで興福寺（法相宗本山）の支配下にあったが、その後真言宗に転じている。
sen.e: Kaijusen-ji Temple also belonged to the Hosso Sect and, until the early modern period, was under the control of Kofuku-ji Temple (head temple of the Hosso Sect) but later converted to the Shingon Sect.

Kaijusen-ji Temple also belonged to the Hosso Sect and, until the early modern period, was under the control of Kofuku-ji Temple (head temple of the Hosso Sect) but later converted to the Shingon Sect.

Kaijusen-ji Temple also belonged to the Hosso Sect and, until the early modern period, was under the control of Kofuku-ji Temple (head temple of the Hosso Sect) but later converted to the Shingon Sect.

sen.j: 五重塔-建保2年（1214年）建立、昭和38年（1962年)解体修理、裳階復元
sen.e: Five-storey pagoda: Constructed in 1214; disassembled, repaired and the pent roof restored in 1962
Five-storey pagoda: Constructed in 1214; disassembled, repaired and the pent roof restored in 1962
Five-storey pagoda: Constructed in 1214; disassembled, repaired and the pent roof restored in 1962

sen.j: 五重塔 - 鎌倉時代（1214年）、裳階付、高さ17.10m、初重総間2.74m
sen.e: Five-storey pagoda: This pagoda created in 1214 during the Kamakura period has a pent roof, stands 17.10m tall and the ground floor bays measure 2.74m.
Five-storey pagoda: This pagoda created in 1214 during the Kamakura period has a pent roof, stands 17.10m tall and the ground floor bays measure 2.74m.
Five-storey pagoda: This pagoda created in 1214 during the Kamakura period has a pent roof, stands 17.10 m tall and the ground floor bays measure 2.74 m.

sen.j: 建保2年（1214年）、貞慶の弟子である慈心上人覚真（藤原道房）が貞慶一周忌供養に建立したもの。
sen.e: It was constructed in 1214 by Jishin Shonin Kakushin (FUJIWARA no Michifusa), Jokei's disciple, to commemorate the first anniversary of his master's death.
It was constructed in 1214 by Jishin Shonin Kakushin (FUJIWARA no Michifusa), Jokei's disciple, to commemorate the first anniversary of his master's death.
It was constructed in 1214 by Jishin Shonin Kakushin (FUJIWARA no Michifusa), Jokei's disciple, to commemorate the first anniversary of his master's death.

sen.j: 屋外にある木造五重塔で国宝・重要文化財に指定されているものとしては、室生寺五重塔に次いで日本で二番目に小さい。
sen.e: The wooden five-storey pagoda, designated both a National Treasure and an Important Cultural Property, is the second smallest five-storey pagoda in Japan after that at Muro-ji Temple.
The wooden five-storey pagoda, designated both a National Treasure and an Important Cultural Property, is the second smallest five-storey pagoda in Japan after that at Muro-ji Temple.
The wooden five-storey pagoda, designated both a National Treasure and an Important Cultural Property, is the second smallest five-storey pagoda in Japan after that at Muro-ji Temple.

sen.j: この塔の特徴は初層内部に心柱がないことで、四天柱（仏壇周囲の4本の柱）に支えられた初層天井の上に心柱が立てられている。
sen.e: This pagoda is unique as its ground storey does not have a center pillar but instead the center pillar extends from the ceiling supported by the four pillars around the altar.
This pagoda is unique as its ground storey does not have a center pillar but instead the center pillar extends from the ceiling supported by the four pillars around the altar.
This pagoda is unique as its ground storey does not have a center pillar but instead the center pillar extends from the ceiling supported by the four pillars around the altar.

sen.j: また裳階（もこし）をもつ五重塔は、海住山寺以外では斑鳩町の法隆寺に存在するだけである。
sen.e: Additionally, the only other five-storey pagoda with a pent roof to exist stands at Horyu-ji Temple in Horyu-cho.
Additionally, the only other five-storey pagoda with a pent roof to exist stands at Horyu-ji Temple in Horyu-cho.
Additionally, the only other five-storey pagoda with a pent roof to exist stands at Horyu-ji Temple in Horyu-cho.
